message.content:
There are twelve main verb tenses in English, which can be divided into three categories: simple, continuous (or progressive), and perfect.

1. Simple Tenses:
   a. Present Simple: Used for habits, general truths, or fixed arrangements.
   b. Past Simple: Used for completed actions in the past.
   c. Future Simple: Used for future events or promises.

2. Continuous (Progressive) Tenses:
   a. Present Continuous: Used for actions happening now or temporary actions.
   b. Past Continuous: Used for actions that were happening when another action interrupted them.
   c. Future Continuous: Used for actions that will be in progress at some point in the future.
   d. Present Perfect Continuous: Used for an action started in the past and continued up to now.
   e. Past Perfect Continuous: Used for an action that was ongoing before another event in the past took place.
   f. Future Perfect Continuous: Used for an action that will have been happening for a certain period by a specific time in the future.

3. Perfect Tenses:
   a. Present Perfect: Used for actions that started in the past and have relevance to now or have recently finished.
   b. Past Perfect: Used for completed actions before another event in the past took place.
   c. Future Perfect: Used for an action that will be completed at a specific time in the future.
   d. Present Perfect Continuous: Used for an ongoing action that started in the past and continues up to now.
   e. Past Perfect Continuous: Used for an action that was ongoing before another event in the past took place.
   f. Future Perfect Continuous: Used for an action that will have been happening for a certain period by a specific time in the future.

Each of these tenses can be formed using the base form of the verb (infinitive without "to") or one of its forms (-ed, -ing).
